src:
Razgledniški pogled na skupno preteklost
Iz Pavlove hiše se je v Plečnikov hodnik NUK preselila razstava razglednic z območja Spodnje Štajerske, ki nas vodi po sledeh skupne preteklosti.
03 Nov 2019, 08:19 by Iztok Ilich



Razstava v Plečnikovem hodniku NUK FOTOGRAFIJE: IZTOK ILICH



Ljutomer za slovensko in nemško čuteče



Razglednica Celja s prečrtanim nemškim imenom Razglednice, kot ta dvojezična, poslana iz Laškega, so bile včasih popisane na obeh straneh.



Slovenski pozdrav na nemški razglednici Trbovelj



Pozdrav Vojku Koprivniku z Lovrenca na Pohorju z značilnim vzklikom Nazdar!



W. Weixl je leta 1942 s pročelja hotela Orel sicer izpraskal slovensko ime, pozabil pa je na napis Kavarna – restavracija v zgornjem oknu.



Pozdrav s Ptuja – ob nemškem imenu mesta



Vodja projektne skupine Heinrich Pfandl


Digitalne tehnologije spreminjajo vsakdanje življenje hitreje in temeljiteje kot vse novotarije v preteklosti. Še posebno opazno pri premagovanju razdalj med ljudmi, ki si želijo kaj sporočiti. Tudi pošta, ki se je po malem razvijala od najstarejših civilizacij do konca 20. stoletja, je v eni generaciji izgubila tradicionalno vlogo in pomen. A najbolj osebne poštne pošiljke, poleg pisem zlasti razglednice, prav zato, ker izginjajo, pridobivajo zgodovinsko vrednost.To prepričljivo dokazuje razstava razglednic Štajer-mark – Po sledeh skupne preteklosti, ki se je iz Pavlove hiše, kulturnega središča Slovencev na južnem Štajerskem v Potrni/Laafeld na avstrijski strani Mure, kjer je nastala, preselila v Ljubljano. Resda v okrnjenem obsegu, z reprodukcijami in pojasnili na panojih, a vsebinsko še vedno zgovorna je na ogled v Plečnikovem hodniku NUK. Postavila jo je Renata Šolar, vodja Kartografske in slikovne zbirke v osrednji slovenski knjižnici.
Virtualna zbirka


Ljutomer za slovensko in nemško čuteče

Ob tej priložnosti sta avstrijska gosta, vodja projektne skupine, slovenist dr. Heinrich Pfandl z Univerze v Gradcu, in Martin Sauerbrey, sodelavec pri projektu, predstavila portal Polos, virtualno zbirko razglednic z območja Spodnje Štajerske. Vanjo so vključene izbrane razglednice iz javnih virov, kot so NUK ter še nekatere slovenske in južnoštajerske knjižnice in arhivi. Del gradiva so prispevali še zasebni zbiralci, Teodor Domej iz Celovca, Walter Lukan z Dunaja in Heinrich Pfandl. Slikovna in podatkovna zbirka Polos je sicer del arhiva Visual Archive of South Eastern Europe (VASE) in omogoča iskanje razglednic na osnovi različnih vsebinskih in jezikovnih meril.Med ponujenimi možnostmi je zanimivo raziskovanje in opazovanje sočasne spodnještajerske zgodovine Slovencev in Nemcev v obdobju 1890–1920, kakor se je zapisala na razglednicah.V tem času so se trenja med pripadniki obeh narodov do konca prve svetovne vojne zaostrovala do oboroženega spopada za severno mejo. Ta skupni imenovalec – sočasen, a praviloma različen pogled enih in drugih na iste pojave in dogodke, kraje in ljudi ter njihove značilne šege in manifestacije – je ključen za razumevanje razmer ob nastajanju prve državne tvorbe južnih Slovanov na tleh razpadle habsburške monarhije.Obračanje po vetruZanimivo je tudi prilagajanje fotografov oziroma založnikov razglednic – bolj iz ekonomskih kot iz nacionalnih razlogov – razmerju sil na južnem Štajerskem. Tiskar in knjigarnar Wilhelm Blanke s Ptuja je na primer takoj po vojni postal Vili/Vilko, nemška imena in pripise na svojih razglednicah – čeprav je sprejemal naročila z obeh strani – pa je zamenjal s slovenskimi. Toda podjetni mož je leta 1941 med nemško okupacijo še enkrat obrnil plašč in svojo založbo preimenoval v Verlag W. Blanke. Podobno je krmaril še en Vilko/Wilhelm Weixl iz Maribora, ki je tudi po drugi vojni s prirejanjem klišejev še naprej tiskal razglednice. Da je napočil povsem nov čas, so pokazale znamke, znameniti verigarji.
Lokalna identiteta


Razglednica Celja s prečrtanim nemškim imenomRazglednice, kot ta dvojezična, poslana iz Laškega, so bile včasih popisane na obeh straneh.

Razstava, ki jo je že ob nastanku pospremil bogat dvojezični katalog, ima tri tematske sklope: Sožitje in sočasnost jezikov, Svet v slikah in Prva svetovna vojna. Avtorji projekta so v njih bolj iskali podobnosti in sorodnosti kot izpostavljali razlike, kar bi neizogibno vodilo v politizacijo. Sto in več let pozneje nepotrebno razpihovanje žerjavice, ki bi bolj kot razkrivanju služilo pristranskemu izkrivljanju preteklosti. Do danes ohranjene podobnosti, so prepričani preučevalci gradiva, izhajajo iz večstoletnega skupnega življenja v kronovini Štajerski, katere južni del, današnja slovenska Štajerska, je bila mešana in dvojezična regija, glavno mesto celote pa je bil Gradec.»Najjužnejši del pokrajine,« še piše v pojasnilih k razstavi, »so še pred sto leti močno zaznamovala mesta s pretežno nemško govorečim prebivalstvom in prevladujoče slovensko govorečim podeželjem. Slovensko in nemško govoreči Štajerci so na tem območju dolga stoletja živeli mirno in v sožitju.« Pri čemer kaže dodati, je bila nemško govoreča polovica gospodarsko, politično in kulturno izrazito premočna. Slovenci so zahteve po svojih narodnih pravicah, zlasti do uporabe jezika, začeli glasneje izražati šele v zadnji tretjini 19. stoletja. Prej so bile bolj kot jezikovna pomembne verska, stanovska in regionalna ali lokalna identiteta, kar je po mnenju razstavljavcev pomenilo, »da je bil posameznik najprej katoličan in Štajerec, meščan ali kmetica, Mariborčanka ali Ptujčan«.
1869 so v Avstro-Ogrski uvedli razglednice.
Prečrtani napisi mest


Pozdrav Vojku Koprivniku z Lovrenca na Pohorju z značilnim vzklikom Nazdar!

Soočanje po narodni pripadnosti je seveda odmevalo tudi v razglednicah, nastalih in poslanih v obdobju, ki ga predstavlja projekt Štajer-mark, le da je bil ta del manj zastopan, kot bi lahko sklepali po politično uravnanem zgodovinopisju. Prav proučevanje razglednic, ki so jih v Avstro-Ogrski uvedli leta 1869, so ugotovili udeleženci v projektu, »nas lahko popelje naravnost v ljudski vsakdan. Medtem ko drugi zgodovinski viri, kot so časopisi, pamfleti, polemike ali politični spomini, rišejo sliko vseodločilnega narodnostnega boja, razglednice kažejo bolj diferencirano in zapleteno podobo.«Razglednice, imenovane tudi korespondenčne karte, listnice ali dopisnice, so omogočale hitrejše pisanje, tudi s svinčnikom in brez vljudnostnih fraz, povrhu je sporočilo praviloma dopolnila slika ali deloma že natisnjeno pozdravno besedilo. Bile so tudi znatno cenejše kot pisma, obenem pa sta se z vstopom zasebnih tiskarjev, fotografov in trgovcev na trg ponudba in izbor motivov bliskovito razširila.Po letu 1900 so prevladale upodobitve pokrajin in krajev ter njihovih pomembnejših zgradb, kot so cerkve, šole, mostovi, tovarne in železniški objekti. Za raziskovalce je bila pri tem zanimiva uporaba jezika: veliko sicer enakih razglednic je bilo natisnjenih samo s slovenskim ali nemškim imenom kraja, nekatere pa so imele v kotu obe imeni – v nemščini pogosto v večjih črkah kot v slovenščini. V takih primerih se je celo dogajalo, da se je dopisovalec naslovniku opravičeval, da ni mogel dobiti razglednice z imenom naselja v njegovem jeziku. Tu in tam je šel kdo še dlje, tako da je na primer nemški napis prečrtal in zraven napisal slovenskega – in obratno.
Vzgojna funkcija


Pozdrav s Ptuja – ob nemškem imenu mesta

Med razglednice, o katerih je znanih veliko podatkov, jih spada tudi 39 iz zapuščine Vojka/Vojteha Koprivnikarja iz narodnozavedne mariborske družine s svojevrstno vzgojno funkcijo: že od otroštva so mu starši in prijatelji pošiljali razglednice z narodno prebudnimi motivi. S sledenjem njihovim sporočilom je raziskovalec lahko po koščkih sestavil deset let Vojkovega življenja.V samostanu Admont se je ohranilo kar 62 razglednic kaplana Lea Sivke, ki si jih je z domačimi in prijatelji enakopravno izmenjeval v slovenščini in nemščini. Različne osebne zgodbe je mogoče razbrati tudi iz številnih drugih dopisovanj; nekatera so se po prvi svetovni vojni končala tako, da je en dopisnik ostal na avstrijski, drugi pa na slovenski strani razmejene Štajerske. Ali pa se je za njimi, tako kot za Ivanom/Hansom/Jankom/Johannom Cizeljem, kot se je podpisoval v obsežni dvojezični korespondenci, po letu 1909 izgubila vsaka sled.
text:
A view of the common past
An exhibition of postcards from the Lower Styria region has moved from Pavel's house to the Plečnik corridor of the NUK, leading us along the traces of our common past.
03 Nov 2019, 08:19 by Iztok Ilich



An Exhibition in the Plečnik Hallway NUK PHOTOGRAPHS: EAST ILICH



Ljutomer for Slovenian and German sentient



Postcard Celje with the crossed-out German name Postcards, such as this bilingual, sent from Laško, were sometimes inscribed on both sides.



Slovenian greeting on the German postcard Trbovelj



Greetings to Vojko Koprivnik from Lawrence on Pohorje with the characteristic Nazdar exclamation!



In 1942, W. Weixl scratched the Slovene name from the front of the Orel Hotel, forgetting the inscription Kavarna - a restaurant in the upper window.



Greetings from Ptuj - next to the German city name



Project Team Leader Heinrich Pfandl


Digital technologies are changing everyday life faster and more fundamentally than all innovations in the past. Particularly noticeable in the distance between people who want to communicate something. Also, mail, which gradually developed from the earliest civilizations to the end of the 20th century, lost its traditional role and importance in one generation. But the most personal postal items, in addition to letters, especially postcards, are disappearing because they are gaining historical value. / Laafeld moved to Ljubljana on the Austrian side of the Mura River where she originated. Although truncated, with reproductions and explanations on billboards, it is still eloquent in content in the Plečnik corridor of the NUK. It was installed by Renata Šolar, Head of the Cartographic and Image Collection at the Central Slovenian Library.
Virtual collection


Ljutomer for Slovenian and German sentient

On this occasion, Austrian guests, project team leader, Slovene dr. Heinrich Pfandl from the University of Graz and Martin Sauerbrey, a collaborator on the project, presented the Polos portal, a virtual collection of postcards from the Lower Styria region. It includes selected postcards from public sources, such as NUK and some other Slovene and South Styrian libraries and archives. Some of the material was contributed by private collectors, Teodor Domej from Klagenfurt, Walter Lukan from Vienna and Heinrich Pfandl. The Polos Image and Database is part of the Visual Archive of South Eastern Europe (VASE) and allows you to search for postcards based on different content and language criteria. By this time, the friction between the two nations had intensified by the end of World War I, until the armed conflict along the northern border. This common denominator - a simultaneous, but generally different, view of the same phenomena and events, places and people and their typical customs and manifestations - is crucial for understanding the conditions at which the first state formation of the southern Slavs was formed on the soil of the collapsed Habsburg Monarchy. it is also an adjustment of photographers or postcard publishers - more for economic than for national reasons - to the balance of power in southern Styria. For example, the printer and bookseller Wilhelm Blanke from Ptuj became Vili / Vilko immediately after the war and replaced the German names and inscriptions on his postcards - although he accepted orders from both sides - with Slovenian ones. But the enterprising man turned his coat once more during the German occupation in 1941 and renamed his record label Verlag W. Blanke. Similarly, another Vilko / Wilhelm Weixl from Maribor navigated, who continued to print postcards after the war with clichés. Brands, famous chainsaws, have shown that a brand new time has come.
Local identity


Postcard Celje with crossed out German namePostcards, such as this bilingual, sent from Laško, were sometimes listed on both sides.

The exhibition, which was accompanied by a rich bilingual catalog at the time of its creation, has three thematic sections: the Coexistence and Concurrency of Languages, the World in Pictures and the First World War. The authors of the project sought more in similarities and relatedness than in exposing differences, which would inevitably lead to politicization. One hundred years and more later, unnecessary bursting of the embers that would serve as biased distortions of the past rather than revealing. Continued similarities to date, the material researchers believe, stem from centuries of cohabitation in the Styria crown, whose southern part, present-day Slovenian Styria, was a mixed and bilingual region, with Graz as the capital of the whole. in the notes to the exhibition, “100 years ago, they were heavily characterized by cities with a predominantly German-speaking population and a predominantly Slovenian-speaking countryside. Slovenian and German-speaking Styrians have lived peacefully and in harmony in the area for many centuries. ”He added that the German-speaking half was extremely strong economically, politically and culturally. Slovenians began to express their demands for their national rights, especially for the use of language, only in the last third of the 19th century. Previously, religious, local and regional or local identities were more important than linguistically, which, according to the exhibitors, meant that "the individual was first Catholic and Styrian, bourgeois or farmer, Maribor or Ptuj."
1869 Postcards were introduced in Austria-Hungary.
The crossed out place inscriptions


Greetings to Vojko Koprivnik from Lawrence on Pohorje with the characteristic Nazdar exclamation!

Clashes by ethnicity were, of course, echoed in postcards produced and sent during the period represented by the Styrian-Mark project, except that this part was less represented than might be inferred from politically balanced historiography. The study of postcards introduced in Austria-Hungary in 1869 was determined by the participants in the project: "It can take us straight to the everyday life. While other historical sources, such as newspapers, pamphlets, controversies, or political memoirs, paint a picture of a decisive national struggle, postcards show a more differentiated and complex image. ”Postcards, also called correspondence cards, wallets, or postcards, made writing faster, even with pencils and no courtesy phrases, as a rule, the message is supplemented by a picture or a partially printed welcome text. They were also significantly less expensive than letters, but with the advent of private printers, photographers and traders, the range and range of motifs expanded rapidly. After 1900, depictions of landscapes and places and their major buildings such as churches, schools, bridges prevailed. , factories and railway facilities. The use of language was interesting for the researchers: many of the same postcards were printed only with the Slovene or German place name, and some of them had both names in the corner - often in larger letters in German than in Slovene. In such cases, it even happened that the correspondent apologized to the addressee for not being able to obtain a postcard with the name of the settlement in his language. Here and there, someone went even further, for example, crossing out the German inscription and writing the Slovene one next to it - and vice versa.
Educational function


Greetings from Ptuj - next to the German city name

Postcards of which much is known, 39 of them are from the legacy of Vojko / Vojteh Koprivnikar from the Maribor family of national consciousness with a peculiar educational function: since childhood his parents and friends have been sending him postcards with nationally awakening motives. By following their messages, the researcher was able to piece together ten years of Vojko's life. As many as 62 postcards of Chaplain Leo Sivka were preserved in the Admont Monastery, which he and his friends and family alike exchanged equally in Slovene and German. Various personal stories can also be learned from many other correspondence; some ended after World War I, leaving one correspondent on the Austrian side and the other on the Slovene side of the demarcated Styria. Or, after them, as with Ivan / Hans / Janko / Johann Cizel, as he signed in a large bilingual correspondence, after 1909 every trace was lost.
